Award.AwardTitle: Mechanisms of Electron-Capture and Electron-Transfer Dissociation
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor John Simons of the University of Utah is supported by the Analytical and Surface Chemistry Program to study the molecular mechanism for electron capture dissociation (ECD) and electron transfer dissociation (ETD) mass spectrometry using theoretical methods. These studies seek better understanding and predictive capability for these relatively new and important approaches to mass spectrometric characterization of biomolecules. They are expected to have important impact in the fields like proteomics, where they may eventually provide means to better control and application of mass spectrometric characterization of the structure of peptides and proteins.

Through collaborations with experimental groups, Prof. Simons' work provides valuable training in both theoretical and analytical methodology to a diverse group of graduate students and postdocs. More broadly, he has been active in providing training opportunities to a wide audience through Internet-based materials and the establishment of summer schools aimed at enhancing the teaching of theoretical physical chemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mass spectrometry has proven to be a very powerful tool for determining the so-called primary structures (i.e., which amino acids are present and in what spatial order) of proteins. The field of proteomics is likely to soon become as important as or more important than that of human genomics. Prof. John Fenn's Nobel Prize winning discovery of how to spray large biomolecules such as proteins into the gas phase was key to allowing the tools of mass spectrometry to be used in proteomics. The discovery in the early 2000s that allowing an electron to attach to a gas-phase charged protein or peptide induces very predictable fragmentations (i.e., at only certain chemical bonds along the protein's backbone) greatly expanded our ability to quickly and reliably determine primary structures. However, understanding where and how, at an atomistic level, an electron attaches and how this one event triggers such a wide range of protein fragmentation events was poorly understood until our NSF grant (CHE 0806160) was undertaken. I close collaboration with several other research groups, we have been able to describe and predict (i) where in the protein an electron is most likely to attach and (ii) at an atomic level, how this event then causes specific chemical bonds along the protein's backbone to  break thus generating the fragment species. As in much of physical science, understanding how things happen and being able to predict when and at what rates they happen is key to being able to improve upon current instrumental tools. It is our expectation that the knowledge gainied in our NSF funded work will help researchers in universities and at instrumentation firms who design next-generation mass spectrometers to generate even more powerful, reliable, and cost-effective methods for probing protein structures, thus advancing the field of proteomics.
